JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Stanislav Shevchuk
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She is represented before ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) are represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant lodged a civil claim with the GPE - ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) against her CARDINAL daughters seeking their eviction from the flat where they were cohabiting and an order requiring them not to impede her use of the flat .
On DATE ORG , following a hearing which the applicant attended , partly allowed her civil claim and ordered her daughters not to impede her use of the flat .
The judgment became final on DATE , none of the parties to the proceedings having filed an appeal within the DATE statutory time - limit . It was served on the applicant on DATE .
According to LAW , a judgment must be publicly pronounced , either fully or in its introductory and operative parts , immediately after the hearing .
Article CARDINAL of the Code , in its relevant part , reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . Copies of the judgment shall be issued to the parties , participating in the hearing , on their request , no later than within DATE following the pronouncement of the judgment .
CARDINAL . The judgment shall be served on the parties , who did not attend the hearing , within DATE following its pronouncement [ ... ] .
CARDINAL . Copies of judgments may be repeatedly issued to the parties at their expense . ”
In practice , written copies of judgments are issued to the parties , who participated in the hearing , only when explicitly requested for .
